title: HDAT9700 Statistical Modelling II Course Outline
text:
Sophisticated modelling techniques are essential for the analysis of real-world health data. Building on Health Data Analytics: Statistical Modelling I (HDAT9600), this course expands the statistical toolkit and broadens studentsâ€™ understanding of relevant statistical approaches for the analysis of realistically complex data structures and research questions. The course is aimed at those currently working or planning on working in health or a health-related field, and who are interested in applying advanced statistical methods to analyse complex data.
Topics covered in this course include multilevel models for hierarchical data; analysis of time series and longitudinal data; methods for drawing causal inferences from observational data; and multiple imputation for missing values.
Content is delivered through a combination of readings, expert guest lectures and practical hands-on tutorials. Statistical concepts are illustrated with a variety of health examples, and students will learn how to implement methods using leading statistical software.





Dr Mark Hanly
Centre for Big Data Research in Health, Level 4, Lowy Building (G25), UNSW Sydney. 02 9385 3143 m.hanly@unsw.edu.au
Students wishing to meet with the course coordinator should make an appointment via email. Virtual Teams meetings or face-to-face meetings on campus are possible.



Dr Mark Hanly (m.hanly@unsw.edu.au)
Dr Md Shajedur Rahman Shawon (s.shawon@unsw.edu.au)




This is a blended learning course comprising of:

Readings and video recordings
Weekly tutorials (Microsoft Teams Meetings for Online student)
Interactive R learnR tutorials

The weekly online tutorial sessions will be recorded and made available for those who cannot make the allotted time. If you do not consent to being recorded, please contact the course convenors ahead of the session.
Students are reminded that UNSW recommends that a 6 units-of-credit course should involve about 150 hours of study and learning activities, equating to 15 hours per week. The formal learning activities are approximately 100 hours throughout the semester and students are expected (and strongly recommended) to do additional hours of self-study.
The workflow of a typical week includes the following activities:

Read/watch the recommended readings/videos
Attend weekly tutorial sessions
Complete the interactive learnR tutorial
Ask questions and join discussions in Teams
Work on assessments

The course is accessed via the course website https://cbdrh-hdat9700.github.io. Core material will be delivered as R learnr documents with explanatory text, embedded videos and interactive coding activities using Rstudio. Assessments will be distributed, completed and submitted using Git and GitHub.


This course assumes proficiency in fitting and interpreting Generalised Linear Models using R or a similar statistical analysis package (e.g.Â Stata/SAS/Python), at a level covered in HDAT9600 Statistical Modelling I. The course is delivered using R so some experience with R programming is expected. Assessments are submitted using Git so familiarity with the Git and GitHub workflow is useful, although not a formal prerequisite.




The course aims to provide students with both conceptual understanding and hands-on experience with a range of statistical modelling techniques relevant to the analysis of health data. On completion of this course students should be able to:

Critique the relative merits of a range of statistical models for analysing health research data
Construct statistical models with appropriate data structures to address distinct health research questions
Compose code using appropriate statistical software to run a range of sophisticated analytic techniques
Appraise model fit using a variety of model diagnostics
Interpret the fitted model parameters from a range of statistical models.




For course evaluation, feedback will be gathered at the completion of the course using the myExperience online student survey. Student feedback is taken seriously, and continual improvements will be made to the course based, in part, on such feedback.





Throughout the course, students will complete summative assessments. In these tasks, students will answer questions, complete coding exercises and interpret results to reinforce the learning covered in the course. Assessments will be distributed, and solutions submitted, using GitHub. Links to the assessment will be posted on the course website. Students are expected to use the standard git workflow to commit and push their completed assessment. Feedback on code may be provide directly through GitHub.



Students are provided with a health research question and a relevant dataset. The assignment requires the production of a 1500-word report, implementing statistical modelling techniques covered in the course to address the research question. This requires developing, coding and interpreting appropriate analysis for the context. Emphasis is given to both the implementation and interpretation of the findings. The assignment is assessed via a rubric.



If you submit assessments late without special consideration, a 5% penalty deduction for every day late will be applied. For example, if you submit an assessment 3 days late, then 15% (5% x 3 days) will be deducted from the assessment mark. Thus, if your assessment was marked as 80% but was submitted 3 days late, then your final mark will be 65% only. Assessments will not be marked if submitted 5 or more days after the assessment due date and will receive a score of 0.






Please see UNSW-Special Consideration and Student Advice-Special Consideration If you find you are going to miss an assessment due to illness, misadventure or circumstances beyond your control, you need to apply for special consideration. To do this:

Tell the course convenors as soon as possible via email. Applications for special consideration will not normally be received more than 3 days after the assessment due date.
Submit supporting evidence. This may include a medical certificate or a supporting email from your supervisor for extenuating work commitments.

If your application for special consideration is approved, your course convenors will discuss with you how you can complete your assessment. Note that all special considerations are handled centrally through the processes described in the links above.
If your request for consideration is granted an alternative assessment deadline will be organised with the course convener.
See: Student-Advice-Reviews and Appeals


See: Student Advice-Student support services.



The UNSW Student Code outlines the standard of conduct expected of students with respect to their academic integrity and plagiarism.
More details of what constitutes plagiarism can be found at https://www.student.unsw.edu.au/plagiarism

title: Propensity score matching
section: So how do we â€œcontrolâ€ for a confounder Z?
text:
So how do we â€œcontrolâ€ for a confounder Z?
1. Stratify by Z
e.g.Â Z = activity level







Activity = High
Activity = Low




Y ~ X | Activity=High
Y ~ X | Activity=Low


lm(y ~ x, data = df[df$activity=="high", ])
m(y ~ x, data = df[df$activity=="low"], )


Y = 3.1 + 2.1X
Y = 3.2 + 2.8X






Useful if effect of X changes for different values of Z (effect modification)
Impractical when a lot of categories or several Z variables

title: Propensity score matching
section: So how do we â€œcontrolâ€ for a confounder Z?
text:
So how do we â€œcontrolâ€ for a confounder Z?
2. Include Z as a regression covariate
Convenient, versatile, widely understood





Y ~ X + Z


lm(y ~ x, data = df)


Y = 3.1 + 2.1X + 0.5Z






BUT need to decide how to specify the model!
\[
\begin{align*}
\text{Linear} \qquad & Y = \beta_0 + {\color{Red} {\beta_{1}}}X + \beta_2 Z \\
\text{Quadratic} \qquad & Y = \beta_0 + {\color{Green} {\beta_{1}}}X + \beta_2 Z + \beta_3 Z^2 \\
\text{Interaction} \qquad & Y = \beta_0 + {\color{Blue} {\beta_{1}}}X + \beta_2 Z_1 + \beta_3 Z_2 + \beta_4 Z_1Z_2 \\
\end{align*}
\]
\({\color{Red} {\beta_{1}}} \ne {\color{Green} {\beta_{1}}} \ne {\color{Blue} {\beta_{1}}}\)
Model dependency! The estimate depends on the model specification

Emulates randomisation
A preprocessing technique (match first then analyse)
Removes model dependency and researcher discretion

title: Propensity score matching
text:
Mahalanobis distance
\[
\text{d}(X_i, X_j) = \sqrt{(X_i-X_j)^TS^{-1}(X_i-X_j)}
\]


\(X_{i}\) is a vector of responses for person \(i\)
\(S\) is the sample variance-covariance matrix of \(X\)

title: Propensity score matching
text:
Mahalanobis distance









Consider the distance from the points a and b to the centre of the data.
The Euclidean distance is about the same but a better reflects the covariance between the variables

Mahalanobis distance
Pros

Standardises variables
Accounts for covariance structure
Emulates a fully blocked randomised experiment

Cons

Doesnâ€™t handle categorical variables well

title: Propensity score matching
text:
Propensity score distance
\[
\begin{align*}
\text{d}(X_i, X_j) &= \hat{\pi_i}-\hat{\pi_j} \\
\text{where} \\
\hat{\pi_i} &= \text{P}(\text{Treatment=1}) \\
&=\text{Probability of receiving treatment/exposure}
\end{align*}
\]


\(\pi_i\) is typically often estimated using logistic regression (but could be any method)
Projects many variables onto one metric
Emulates a completely randomised control experiment

title: Propensity score matching
text:
Propensity score distance
Pros

Highly flexible & works with diverse variable types
Reduces many variables into a single variable

Cons

Ignores local information

title: Propensity score matching
text:
Summary


Three identifiability conditions allow us to make causal claims from observational data

Positivity
Exchangeability
Consistency

In a well-designed RCT, these assumptions are plausible
For observational data we have to adjust the analysis to make these more plausible
Matching allows us to find an RCT â€˜hiddenâ€™ in observational data

Balances data before modelling, removing model dependency
Propensity score matching: a simple randomised control trial
Other types of matching: a fully blocked randomised trial

Check common support (positivity assumption) and covariate balance (exchangeability assumption)

So when do we use DAGs?


Intuitively we know that something might be up in these examples.
DAGs are useful:

When we are answering a causal question

Especially when we have observational data
We want to think through cause and effect



Correlation does not equal causation


Draw your assumptions before your conclusions

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
text:
Graphical rules of covariate selection
Backdoor path criterion (informally!)
To estimate the causal effect of X on Y we must close all backdoor paths between X and Y

What is a backdoor path?
When is a path closed?

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
text:
Backdoor paths

A causal path is any path between exposure X and outcome Y where all the arrows point from X towards Y
A backdoor path is any path between exposure X and outcome Y that is not a causal path, i.e.Â at least one arrow points back towards X









The path x â†’ m â†’ y is a causal path








The path x â† z â†’ y is a backdoor path

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
section: When is a path open or closed?
text:
When is a path open or closed?

A path is open if it transmits statistical association.









The path Maternal age â† Socio-economic status â†’ Birth weight is open.

How would we address this in practice?




Maternal age and birthweight may be correlated even though maternal age does not have an effect on birth weight

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
text:
Summary


There are three tasks of data science: description, prediction and causal inference
When performing causal inference, variable selection must be informed by an understanding of the underlying causal data-generation process
DAGs help us to formalise and communicate our assumptions about causal processes
DAGs also help inform variable selection, by applying backdoor path criterion.

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Pre-reading
Key points


In 1999, UK solicitor Sally Clarke was wrongly convicted of killing her two infant sons (who died 13 months apart)
She ultimately served over three years in prison before her conviction was overturned
The defence argued that the probability of two deaths was 1 in 73 million
Based on an estimated probability of Sudden Infant Death for each child of around 1 in 8500 (1/8500 X 1/8500 ~= 1/73000000)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Challenges in this analysis


Usual GLM ignores that patients attending the same hospital have similar characteristics
Canâ€™t add 313 dummy variables for each hospital in NSW (RQ2)
Or if we did, we couldnâ€™t also control for hospital-level variables, e.g.Â hospital type, hospital size.

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
The solution?

Multilevel models!



Appropriately reflect dependence in the data
Address more interesting research questions

Does quality of administrative data vary by hospital?
What patient and hospital characteristics predict an outcome?
Do patient and hospital characteristics interact to influence an outcome?

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
An example closer to home




Lujic et al (2014). Variation in the recording of common health conditions in routine hospital data. BMJ Open.


Results

Significant between-hospital variation was found (ranging from 8% of unexplained variation for diabetes to 22% for heart disease)
Implications for comparisons involving heart disease based solely on hospital data

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
section: How is a multilvel model operationalised?
text:
How is a multilvel model operationalised?

Itâ€™s all about the residuals

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text: Single level residuals

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Single level residuals

The residual is the difference between the observed value and the predicted value

\[
e_3 = y_3 - \hat{y_3}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text: Multilevel residuals

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Multilevel residuals

Decompose into group-level residuals & within-group residuals
\[
e_3 = u_2 + e_{12}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Multilevel residuals
Both sets of residuals are assumed to come from a normal distribution
Level 1 residuals
\[
e_{ij} \sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{e})
\]


Mean 0
Fixed variance \(\sigma^2_{e}\)



Level 2 residuals
\[
u_{0j} \sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{u0})
\]


Mean 0
Fixed variance \(\sigma^2_{u0}\)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Aside














Mathematical notation


This little bad boy is a lower case sigma, the 18th letter of the Greek alphabet.
In statistics, \(\sigma\) is conventionally used to represent the standard deviation. we will be talking a lot about the variance, which is the square of the standard deviation \(\sigma^2\).
You may have also met \(\sigma\)â€™s big brother \(\Sigma\), which looks different but is pronounced the same. \(\Sigma\) is conventionally used to indicate the sum of a series of numbers.

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Variance components model
An empty two-level multilevel model
\[
\begin{align*}
y_{ij} &= \beta_0 + u0_j + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
u_{0j} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{u0}) \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{e})
\end{align*}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Variance components model
These are the parameters we estimate
\[
\begin{align*}
y_{ij} &= {\color{red}{\beta_0}} + u0_j + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
u_{0j} &\sim \text{N}(0,{\color{red}{\sigma^2_{u0}}}) \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,{\color{red}{\sigma^2_{e}}})
\end{align*}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
The Variance Partition Coefficient (VPC)
The proportion of variance at level 2
\[
VPC = \frac{\sigma^2_{u0}}{\sigma^2_{u0} + \sigma^2_{e}}
\]


â€œ20% of variation in patientâ€™s outcome was attributable to the hospital they were admitted toâ€

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Interpreting the VPC


A


B



Which plot shows higher VPC, A or B?

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Interpreting the VPC


A


B



The answer is Plot B - most of the variation in the data is attributable to the higher level, e.g.Â the groups.

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text: Random intercept model

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Random intercept model




\[
\begin{align*}
y_{ij} &= \beta_0 + \beta X_{ij}+ u0_j + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
u_{0j} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{u0}) \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{e})
\end{align*}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Random intercept model




\[
\begin{align*}
y_{ij} &= {\color{red}{\beta_0}} + {\color{red}{\beta}}X_{ij} + u0_j + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
u_{0j} &\sim \text{N}(0,{\color{red}{\sigma^2_{u0}}}) \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,{\color{red}{\sigma^2_{e}}})
\end{align*}
\]




One or more X covariates
Covariates can be at level 1, level 2 or even an interaction between level 1 and level 2
Group level lines are parallel

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text: Random intercept - random slope model

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Random intercept - random slope model




\[
\begin{align*}
y_{ij} &= \beta_0 + \beta X_{ij} + u0_j + u1_j + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
\begin{pmatrix} u0_j \\ u1_j \end{pmatrix} &\sim
\text{MVN}\begin{pmatrix} \sigma^2_{u0} & \sigma_{01} \\ \sigma_{01} & \sigma^2_{u1} \end{pmatrix} \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{e})
\end{align*}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Random intercept - random slope model




\[
\begin{align*}
y_{ij} &= {\color{red}{\beta_0}} + {\color{red}{\beta}} X_{ij} + u0_j + u1_j + e_{ij} \\[10pt] \begin{pmatrix} u0_j \\ u1_j \end{pmatrix} &\sim \text{MVN}\begin{pmatrix} {\color{red}{\sigma^2_{u0}}} & {\color{red}{\sigma_{01}}} \\ \sigma_{01} & {\color{red}{\sigma^2_{u1}}} \end{pmatrix} \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,{\color{red}{\sigma^2_{e}}})
\end{align*}
\]




The level 2 residuals are assumed to be drawn from a multivariate normal distribution, introducing a new covariance parameter \(\sigma_{01}\)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Interpreting the covariance parameter


A


B



Which plot shows positive covariance \(\sigma_{01}\), A or B?

title: Multilevel Modelling Part I - Introduction
text:
Interpreting the covariance parameter


A


B



The answer is Plot B - groups with an above average random intercept have an above average random slope

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
text:
Motivating example
With a multilevel model we can incorporate multiple views
\[
\begin{align*}
\text{incontinence}_{ij} &= \beta_0 + \beta_1 \text{Time}_{ij} + \beta_2 \text{Surgery}_{ij} + u0_j + u1_j\text{Time} + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
\begin{pmatrix} u0_j \\ u1_j \end{pmatrix} &\sim
\text{MVN}\begin{pmatrix} \sigma^2_{u0} & \sigma_{01} \\ \sigma_{01} & \sigma^2_{u1} \end{pmatrix} \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{e})
\end{align*}
\]


Which parameter answers which question?

Is there an improvement over time? \({\color{red}{\beta_1}}\)
Are there differences by surgery or radiotherapy? \({\color{red}{\beta_2}}\)
Do outcomes vary for different patients? \({\color{red}{\sigma^2_{u0}}} \text{ and } {\color{red}{\sigma^2_{u1}}}\)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
section: Part 2. Special features of growth curve models
text: Part 2. Special features of growth curve models

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
section: Growth curve models are a special type of multilevel model
text:
Growth curve models are a special type of multilevel model





What would we add to this model to make it a growth curve model?
\[
\begin{align*}
\text{incontinence}_{ij} &= \beta_0 + \beta_1 \text{Time}_{ij} + \\
& + u0_j + u1_j\text{Time} + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
\begin{pmatrix} u0_j \\ u1_j \end{pmatrix} &\sim
\text{MVN}\begin{pmatrix} \sigma^2_{u0} & \sigma_{01} \\ \sigma_{01} & \sigma^2_{u1} \end{pmatrix} \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{e})
\end{align*}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
section: Growth curve models are a special type of multilevel model
text:
Growth curve models are a special type of multilevel model




What would we add to this model to make it a growth curve model?
\[
\begin{align*}
\text{incontinence}_{ij} &= \beta_0 + \beta_1 \text{Time}_{ij} + {\color{red}{\beta_2 \text{Time}^2_{ij}}} + \\
& + u0_j + u1_j\text{Time} + e_{ij} \\[10pt]
\begin{pmatrix} u0_j \\ u1_j \end{pmatrix} &\sim
\text{MVN}\begin{pmatrix} \sigma^2_{u0} & \sigma_{01} \\ \sigma_{01} & \sigma^2_{u1} \end{pmatrix} \\[10pt]
e_{ij} &\sim \text{N}(0,\sigma^2_{e})
\end{align*}
\]

text: How do we parameterise time?

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
text:
Variance-covariance structure of the residuals

We usually assume that the level 1 errors are â€œwhite noiseâ€
i.e.Â there is no structure in the errors
\(e_i \sim \text{N}(0, \sigma_e^2)\)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
text:
Variance-covariance structure of the residuals
Another way of expressing that is saying there is no covariance in the errors.

\[
\sigma_e^2
\times
\begin{bmatrix}
\text{Hospital}  &   & {\color{red}{\text{A}}} & {\color{red}{\text{A}}} & {\color{red}{\text{A}}} & {\color{green}{\text{B}}} & {\color{green}{\text{B}}} & {\color{green}{\text{B}}} \\
  & \text{Patient} & {\color{navy}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{3}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{3}}} \\
{\color{red}{\text{A}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{1}}} & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{red}{\text{A}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{2}}} & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{red}{\text{A}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{3}}} & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{green}{\text{B}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{1}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{green}{\text{B}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{2}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
{\color{green}{\text{B}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{3}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}
\]



The residual for patient 1 in hospital j is unrelated to the residual for patient 2 in hospital j
This is plausible for patients nested within hospitals

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
text:
Variance-covariance structure of the residuals
But what about observations nested within individuals?

\[
\sigma_e^2
\times
\begin{bmatrix}
\text{Patient}  &   & {\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{green}{\text{2}}} \\
  & \text{Observation} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} \\
{\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
{\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}
\]
Is it still plausible that the off diagonal elements are 0?

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
text:
Variance-covariance structure of the residuals

A common concern is autocorrelation: measures over time are correlated.
Correlation between errors at different time points can captured with just one additional parameter \(\rho\) (â€œrhoâ€)


\[
\sigma_e^2
\times
\begin{bmatrix}
\text{Patient}  &   & {\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{green}{\text{2}}} \\
  & \text{Observation} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} \\
{\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & 1 & \rho & \rho^2 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & \rho & 1 & \rho & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{red}{\text{1}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} & \rho^2 & \rho & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
{\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{i}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & \rho & \rho^2 \\
{\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{ii}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & \rho & 1 & \rho \\
{\color{green}{\text{2}}} & {\color{navy}{\text{iii}}} & 0 & 0 & 0 & \rho^2 & \rho & 1
\end{bmatrix}
\]
\(\rho \lt 1\) so \(\rho^2 << \rho\)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
text:
Aside














Mathematical notation


This little bad boy is the letter rho, the 17th letter of the Greek alphabet.
\(\rho\) is used to represent numerous quantities in mathematics and science. You can read more here.

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
text:
Variance-covariance structure of the residuals





Many different structures are possible
We can explore different structures and compare models

title: Multilevel Modelling Part III
section: Fitting Growth Curve Models in R
text:
Fitting Growth Curve Models in R


lme4

Advantages


Faster
Can fit more models (e.g.Â binary outcome)


Syntax


lmer(y ~ x + (1 | group), 
     data=df )



nlme

Advantages


Allows for variance-covariance structures for the residuals (e.g.Â autocorrelation)


Syntax


lmer(y ~ x, 
     random = ~1 | group, 
     data=df )

text:

Growth curve models are a special type of multilevel model
Applies to repeated measures data
Choice of parameterization for time (linear/polynomial/splines)
Flexible error covariance structure to capture correlation between errors at different time points
Advantages to nlme package in R

title: Multilevel Modelling Part II
text:
Model building

Start simple | slowly add complexity | compare at each step



Single level null model


\(y_i = \beta_0\)




Random intercept null model


\(y_i = \beta_0 + u0_j\)




Add fixed part variables


\(y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1X1_{ij} + \beta_2X2_{ij} + u0_j\)




Test random slope if relevant


\(y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1X1_{ij} + \beta_2X2_{ij} + u0_j +u1_jX1_{ij}\)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part II
text:
Model comparison
1. Check variance partition coefficient to assess if multilevel model is suitable

Recall, the variance partition coefficient (VPC) is the proportion of variance at level 2 in an empty model


\[
VPC = \frac{\sigma^2_{u0}}{\sigma^2_{u0} + \sigma^2_e}
\]

title: Multilevel Modelling Part II
text:
Model comparison
3. Model comparison statistics






Recall from HDAT9600â€¦


AIC and BIC

Lower values of AIC and BIC indicate a better fitting model
The units have no real interpretation, only for comparison
The BIC penalises more heavily for adding additional covariates

Likelihood ratio test

The LR test is for nested models only
Null hypothesis is that the the smaller model provides as good a fit for the data as the larger model
Significant test statistic suggests larger model is better

title: Multilevel Modelling Part II
text:
Analysis of binary outcomes

We model the probability that outcome is a â€œsuccessâ€

\(\text{Pr}(y_{ij}=1) = \pi_{ij}\)



We fit a logistic regression model with a group level residual \(u0_j\)

\(\text{log}(\frac{\pi_{ij}}{1-\pi_{ij}}) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X_{ij} + u0_j\)



As usual, we assume these residuals are normally distributed with a fixed variance

\(u0_j\sim\text{N}(0, \sigma^2_e)\)

title: Multilevel Modelling Part II
text:
Analysis of binary outcomes






The VPC statistic in multilvel logistic regression


\[
VPC = \frac{\sigma^2_{u0}}{\sigma^2_{u0} + \color{red}{3.29}}
\] Because there is no within-group residual we replace the level one variance with the variance from the logistic distribution \(\frac{\pi^2}{3}â‰ˆ3.29\)

mod4 <- lmer(MathAch ~ 1 + SES + (1|School), 
            data=MathAchieve)

g <- MathAchieve %>% 
  filter(School %in% c('8367', '2658', '2277', '9586')) %>% 
    ggplot() + 
    geom_point(aes(x = SES, 
                   y = MathAch, 
                   group=School)) + 
    geom_line(aes(x = SES, 
                  y = p4, 
                  group=School)) + 
    labs(x = "SES", y = 'Match achievement') +
    theme(legend.position = 'none') + 
    facet_wrap(~School, ncol=2)

PlotCode









Code to generate the caterpillar plot

ranef(mod4) %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  arrange(condval) %>% 
      ggplot(aes(x = 1:nrow(re), y = condval)) + 
        geom_hline(aes(yintercept=0), color='red') +

        geom_linerange((aes(ymin = condval - 1.96*condsd,
